Back to Franz Liszt

Franz Liszt

Douze Études d’exécution transcendante, S. 139

1851 · LW A172 · R. 2b

[Wikipedia] · [IMSLP]

Total duration: 65' 30"

  • 1. Preludio
  • 2. A minor
  • 3. Paysage
  • 4. Mazeppa
  • 5. Feux-follets
  • 6. Vision
  • 7. Eroica
  • 8. Wilde Jagd
  • 9. Ricordanza
  • 10. F minor
  • 11. Harmonies du soir
  • 12. Chasse-neige

These études exist in three versions: the Douze Études (S. 136; LW A8; R. 1) from 1826, the Douze Grandes études (S. 137; LW A39; R. 2a) from 1837–1838, and the Douze Études d’exécution transcendante (S. 139; LW A172; R. 2b) from 1851.

S. 136/S. 137/S. 139/
1–61–61–6
–77
8–108–108–10
71111
11––
121212

The fourth étude also exists in a further version, Mazeppa (S. 138; LW A172; R. 2c), that is a slight revision of the version found in S. 137. The étude was later used as the basis of the symphonic poem Mazeppa (S. 100; LW G7; R. 417), which also exists in versions for piano duet (S. 594; LW B38; R. 320), two pianos (S. 640; LW C13; R. 362) and solo piano (S. 511b, a revision of an arrangement by Theophil Forchhammer).

The S. 136 and S. 137 versions were intended to contain further études to complete the series of keys; the Allegro maestoso in F-sharp major (S. 692c; LW A8/13) is likely a fragment of a thirteenth étude for the S. 136 set.

Recommended editions

  • New Liszt Edition (Editio Musica Budapest) · I/1 · Z. A/B 5411 · Studies I · ed. Zoltán Gárdonyi / István Szelényi
  • New Liszt Edition (Editio Musica Budapest) · Suppl. 4 · Z. A/B 14499 · ed. Adrienne Kaczmarczyk [album leaf for no. 11]
  • Henle · HN 717 · ed. Ernst-Günter Heinemann
  • Wiener Urtext · UT 50233 · ed. Christian Ubber

1. Preludio

Duration: 1'

Difficulty: 4

2. A minor

Duration: 2' 30"

Difficulty: 5

3. Paysage

Duration: 5' 30"

Difficulty: 3.5

4. Mazeppa

Duration: 7' 30"

Difficulty: 5

5. Feux-follets

Duration: 4'

Difficulty: 5

6. Vision

Duration: 5' 30"

Difficulty: 4.5

7. Eroica

The introduction of this étude is based on the introduction of the Impromptu brillant sur des thèmes de Rossini et Spontini (S. 150; LW A5; R. 29).

Duration: 4' 30"

Difficulty: 5

8. Wilde Jagd

Liszt used the same title for Wilde Jagd (Scherzo) (S. 176a), which is an earlier version of the Scherzo und Marsch (S. 177; LW A174; R. 20).

Duration: 5'

Difficulty: 5

9. Ricordanza

Duration: 10' 30"

Difficulty: 4.5

10. F minor

Duration: 5'

Difficulty: 5

11. Harmonies du soir

Duration: 9'

Difficulty: 4.5

12. Chasse-neige

Duration: 5' 30"

Difficulty: 5
